timeline.summary: Andrew, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York, is requesting certification of an AT&T record (file code 229703, dated 8/23/2006). He provides a PDF scan and a cover letter, attached to a CD, for this certification request to gtdc@att.com. He includes contact information for questions or difficulties.

Joseph DiPiero of Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld LLC is providing an additional production of documents to respond to a July 11, 2019 subpoena on behalf of Deutsche Bank. The production, along with a cover letter and updated index, is attached to an email sent to Parvin Mo ne, James Ben amin, and Thomas Moyer. A password for accessing the production will be sent separately.

Kelsey Russell of WilmerHale sent a cover letter to accompany JPMorgan Chase’s production in response to grand jury subpoenas issued between August 11, 2019 and October 9, 2019. The cover letter details the production and instructs the recipient to download it with a provided password. The email contains standard confidentiality and disclaimer information from WilmerHale.

On November 19, 2019, Citrix Attachments sent a production of documents to an unspecified recipient in response to a July 11, 2019 subpoena from the SDNY. The production included files named "2019.11.19 DB Submission to SDNY.pdf", "Appendix A.xlsx", "Appendix B.pdf", and "DB-SDNY-Prod011.zip" (287.3 MB). An earlier submission had a mislabeled file, which Citrix Attachments corrected and provided a revised copy. A cover letter and updated production index were also included.

An attorney, Andrew Patel, is discussing disclosure strategies regarding a case involving Mr. Epstein with the government. Patel proposes a disclosure cover letter modeled after a US government disclosure in *United States v. Madonna*. He offers to produce redacted notes to the government, suggesting a protective order to prevent disclosure. The government previously sent unredacted notes and is proposing to produce redacted copies along with Mr. Epstein’s name and contact information on an AEO basis, changing the file names to include Bates numbers. Patel requests a copy of the planned disclosure to help formulate a strategy.

UBS Financial Services Inc. received a grand jury subpoena dated June 29, 2020. Jezebel Diaz, a paralegal and authorized officer at UBS Group AG’s Legal — Subpoenas, Levies & Garnishments department, sent UBS returns (attached as a zip file) to a recipient via email. The documents included a cover letter and a password-protected production related to the subpoena. The email flagged the message as not virus scanned due to encrypted data.

A protective order proposal was drafted by defense counsel (Laura Menninger and Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C.) regarding a case involving pretrial publicity and discovery. The proposal includes clarifications and modifications to a previous version, specifically addressing: *   Defining “Confidential” information, aligning with Second Circuit case law and privacy rights. *   Removing a “Highly Confidential” category. *   Suggesting a laptop-based access for the government to provide the client with confidential discovery materials for review while in custody. *   Requiring explicit marking of documents as confidential rather than relying on cover letters. *   Maintaining the ability for the party receiving the order to dispute designations. The sender (Christian Everdell) emphasizes the importance of a jury trial and the need to protect witnesses from harassment, advocating for equitable access to discovery for all parties.  A confidentiality notice is included in each email.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested protocol for delivering a hard drive containing discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell at MDC. The response outlined the procedure: mailing the drive to the legal department, etching it with a number, providing an authorization memo, and including a cover letter with the password if the drive is password-protected. The protocol indicated non-encrypted drives were preferred for inmate discovery materials.

An Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York requested protocol for delivering a hard drive containing discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell at MDC. The recipient advised mailing the drive to the facility’s legal department, etching it with a number, and providing an authorization memo. They also suggested the drive be password protected with a cover letter containing the password. The recipient confirmed the drive should not be encrypted.

*   A suggestion was made to send all current discovery materials on each drive to avoid multiple drives with varying content. *   One hard drive was delivered on August 7, 2020, and the tracking information confirms this. *   Instructions were given for mailing the hard drives to the facility’s legal department, including numbering the drives and providing an authorization memo. *   The protocol for handling discovery drives for inmates involves non-encrypted drives and a cover letter containing the password. *   Confirmation of delivery was received and an update on the delivery process was requested.

An email chain discusses the delivery of a hard drive containing discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC. The hard drive was delivered on August 7, 2020, at 7:16 AM, according to FedEx tracking. A subsequent email outlines protocol: the drive should be etched with a number, accompanied by an authorization memo, and potentially password-protected with a cover letter containing the password. The original sender indicates that non-encrypted drives are preferred for inmate use. The tracking number for the drive is EFTA00026713.

A request was made to deliver a hard drive containing discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell at MDC. The protocol for delivery involved mailing the drive to the facility’s legal department, requiring it to be etched with a number, accompanied by an authorization memo, and potentially password-protected with a cover letter containing the password. The sender inquired about the current protocol and whether the drive needed to be non-encrypted. A response confirmed the requested protocol and emphasized the need for verification of the package’s location.

An email was sent from an attorney to counsel regarding the production of discovery materials in the case of US v. Maxwell. The email includes a cover letter and the password "Sest" for accessing the production. The production was conducted on August 21, 2020.

On September 2, 2020, Kelsey D. Russell of WilmerHale sent a cover letter to [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] regarding a JPMorgan Chase production in response to grand jury subpoenas issued between August 11, 2019 and October 9, 2019. The cover letter was forwarded by [REDACTED]. Russell indicated that access to the production should be fine and offered to assist with any issues. The email included standard confidentiality disclaimers from WilmerHale.

A cover letter to PAE, attached as 2020.11.02_Cover Letter to_PAE.docx, was sent by ‘cl’ to the Assistant United States Attorney, Southern District of New York, on November 2, 2020. The document is associated with EFTA00030528.

The document details the preparation and delivery of discovery materials related to the US v. Maxwell case. Key points include: *   Three PDFs – “Maxwell Discovery Letter,” “Maxwell MAIN,” and “Maxwell PASSWORD” – were created and sent to the MDC. *   The PDFs contained instructions for loading onto drives and mailing to Maxwell and the attorneys. *   A cover letter with instructions for viewing problem files was also prepared. *   Drive encryption requests were made for both Maxwell's and the defense's drives. *   A courier (Tom Powers) was scheduled to deliver the drives to the CSOs for delivery to Maxwell and the MDC. *   The intention was to have Maxwell begin reviewing the discovery materials over the weekend.

On November 12, 2020, an attorney at the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York sent disclosures to multiple recipients regarding the Robert Adams case. These disclosures, attached as “Adams_Disclosuressd.docx,” were based on review of witness interviews and input from agents. The disclosures were intended for incorporation into a discovery cover letter and were submitted with a deadline of the following day.

The Southern District of New York, via an Assistant United States Attorney, is producing materials related to victims not referenced in Indictment number 20 Cr. 330 (AJN) as per a court order dated November 18, 2020. The materials are being offered for production via FTP, and a CD containing a copy will be sent to the MDC for review by the client.

A paralegal specialist at the U.S. Attorney’s Office in SDNY is sending out cover letters for a 5th Production defense. These include a cover letter for defense counsel and two cover letters for Maxwell, one for inclusion with a drive sent to MDC and another containing a password for a separate envelope also sent to MDC. Approval is needed before the drives are sent out.

An email chain discusses revisions to cover letters for the 5th Production. The MDC cover letters were approved with a date change to 10/20, and the counsel cover letter was revised incorporating previously discussed language. The original email requests confirmation of the edits before sending the cover letters and associated drives to the MDC.

A paralegal specialist from the U.S. Attorney's Office SDNY is preparing a drive for defense containing materials for production in the *US v Maxwell* case. The drive includes the iPhone data (NYC024318 1871) with a tentative Bates number. A cover letter and updated index are being prepared and will be sent to defense. Another individual is working on copying the MDC drive, and the paralegal is available to make changes to the cover letter and/or index as needed.

A SANYS contractor is sending a revised draft letter regarding the "Sixth Production" to the U.S. Attorney’s Office SDNY. The contractor requests a double-check of the index for devices with just images and confirms the upload of iPhone materials to a drive for defense. A cover letter and updated index are attached, including a unique index for the MDC drive. One contractor is still working on copying the MDC drive.

An email exchange occurred between individuals identified as [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] regarding a cover letter for case EFTA00021356. One party requested a prior letter from the case to use as a reference and indicated an inability to work on the shared drive. An attached document titled "GM renewed bail motion cover letter" (dated 2020-12-16) was sent as part of the exchange.

On December 16, 2020, the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York submitted documents in opposition to a defendant’s renewed bail application in the case of *US v. Maxwell, 20 CR. 330 (AJN)*. The submission included a cover letter, memorandum of law, Government Exhibits A and B, and a proposed redaction document for the memorandum of law. The documents were sent to Nathan NYSD Chambers and several attorneys including Christian Everdell, BOBBI C STERNHEIM, and Jeff Pagliuca.

An email chain discusses the delivery of CDs containing Eighth Production materials and a password for the CDs. The CDs include cover letters sent to defense counsel. A FedEx tracking number (816289189888) is associated with the shipment. The email is from a Paralegal Specialist at the U.S. Attorney’s Office, SDNY.

The email chain concerns the production of documents for a legal case, specifically related to PAE drives and iPhone images. A contractor is tasked with: *   Creating password-protected discs containing iPhone images. *   Redacting Bates numbers and updating a cover letter to reflect the contents. *   Preparing a final report with images. *   Making copies of the PAE drives for internal use. *   Coordinating with Maxwell and another party to ensure timely delivery and address potential delays. *   Providing a password-protected copy of the PAE drive for internal use.

On December 17, 2020, an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent a new discovery production for Ghislaine Maxwell via FedEx. The production included copies of cover letters and related documents.

On December 18, 2020, a paralegal specialist at the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) identified seven items – one Excel file and six PDFs – from the Maxwell case discovery that required reproduction due to incorrect Bates numbers. The specialist intended to re-stamp and update these items, draft a cover letter detailing the changes, and send the reproductions and a disc to MDC via email and physical delivery. The emails exchanged confirmed the issue and the specialist's plan to resolve it quickly.

A United States Attorney sent a laptop, power cord, cover memo, a hard drive with a new discovery production, and two cover letters to Maxwell for her review of discovery materials. A previous hard drive containing file replacements was also shipped via FedEx. The Attorney requested confirmation that the drive was delivered to Maxwell.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan regarding a typographical error in a reply brief for the case *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330). The email requested approval to correct the error on pages 1 and 8 of the memorandum.  He attached both the unredacted and redacted versions of the memorandum, along with exhibits A-B, to be filed under seal. The email also included a cover letter and confidentiality notices.

Maxwell. *   They are requesting a 4TB hard drive containing the complete discovery production, which is not yet ready. *   They are questioning the correlation of Bates numbers to subject devices in the discovery cover letters. *   They are requesting an unredacted FBI report and a log of redactions. *   They identify missing documents, including AT&T subscriber information and flight logs, and request their production. *   They point out metadata inconsistencies in the PROD011 and PROD015 production files. *   They request a copy of the government’s detailed index of documents. *   They are requesting copies of grand jury subpoenas and their associated date ranges. *   They inquire about the unsealing of a cell-site simulator affidavit referenced in a news article and requests confirmation of any related FOIA releases.

A communication from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York to [REDACTED] regarding “Maxwell motions 1 of 3.” The communication includes attachments: a zipped file dated 1.25.2021 containing filings, and a cover letter dated 1.25.2021 to Judge Nathan regarding pretrial motions. The case identifier is EFTA00011444.

The Government of the Southern District of New York submitted an omnibus memorandum of law in opposition to the defense’s pretrial motions in the case of *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The memorandum, along with supporting exhibits and a cover letter, were initially requested to be accepted temporarily under seal.

A United States Attorney’s Office from the Southern District of New York sent a discovery production (2021.02.26_Tenth_Production.zip) and a cover letter (2021.02.26_Maxwell_Discovery_Letter.pdf) to [REDACTED] in connection with the case *US v. Maxwell, 20 CR. 330 (AIN)*. The password for the production is provided.

*   A legal team (Chris Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP) is proposing redactions to Exhibit 11 and their letter dated March 9, 2021, regarding redactions. *   The redactions are based on a court order (Judge Nathan’s) to redact portions of deposition transcripts and related documents that were originally filed in a defamation case and remain sealed. *   Specifically, they are requesting redactions to include “[Minor Victim-2]” on page 134 and to redact quotations/references from a document (Exhibit H) that is also under seal. *   The opposing legal team (EFTA00019475) initially questioned the need for the redactions but ultimately agrees to the proposed redactions, deferring to Chris’s decision on the redactions of Exhibit H. *   They are scheduling a meeting to discuss the redactions further.

On March 12, 2021, the United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) sent a revised discovery production to Cohen & Gresser LLP regarding the case *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The initial index in a previous cover letter incorrectly started at the wrong Bates number. The attached production relates to materials regarding victims not referenced in Indictment number S1 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), ordered by the court on November 18, 2020. The production was intended to be sent via FTP and a CD would also be provided for review.

Bobbi C. Sternheim, Esq., of the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Sternheim, sent an email on March 16, 2021, to provide an unredacted version of a Reply Memorandum In Support of Ms. Maxwell’s pending bail application, as required by Rule 2(8) of the Court’s individual rules. The email was accompanied by a cover letter (attached as a PDF) and included a Covid-19 notice regarding the office closure and preferred communication methods. The document’s contents are considered confidential and privileged.

Bobbi C. Sternheim, Esq., sent an email to Nathan NYSD Chambers and others, including Christian Everdell and Laura Menninger, regarding an unredacted version of the Reply Memorandum In Support of Ms. Maxwell’s pending bail application in the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The email was attached to a cover letter and submitted pursuant to Rule 2(8) of the court's individual rules. Sternheim’s firm was providing the document to the court and government.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent a filing to Judge Nathan regarding the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). The filing includes redacted and unredacted versions of Ms. Maxwell’s reply memoranda and accompanying exhibits in support of her pretrial motions, submitted pursuant to Rule 2(B) of the court’s rules. A redacted cover letter is being filed on the public docket.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan regarding the filing of redacted and unredacted versions of Ghislaine Maxwell’s reply memoranda and exhibits in support of her pretrial motions in the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The attachments included a zip file containing the memoranda and exhibits, along with several image files. A redacted cover letter was filed on the public docket.

An email exchange between Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP and an unknown recipient regarding proposed redactions to Exhibit 11. The redactions, as outlined in Judge Nathan’s order, target quotations and references from a previously filed, sealed document (Exhibit H). The sender seeks confirmation from the recipient regarding whether the redactions should remain in place, deferring to the recipient's decision. Attached documents include proposed redactions and the original opposition brief.

The U.S. Department of Justice, specifically the Southern District of New York, is responding to a request from legal counsel (Cohen & Gresser LLP, Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., and Bobbi Stemheim) regarding documents related to the Ghislaine Maxwell investigation. Specifically, the request included: *   Documents produced to Radar Online via FOIA. *   Any other FOIA requests pertaining to Jeffrey Epstein or Ghislaine Maxwell investigations. *   Materials reflecting the FBI-New York Office’s involvement in the USAO-SDFL investigation. The DOJ states they are not providing the requested materials due to: *   Lack of legal basis for the FOIA requests (Rule 16, etc.). *   FOIA’s purpose is public disclosure, not private litigation. *   The FBI has already made the Radar Online materials publicly available on its website. The DOJ is providing: *   Cover letters accompanying the Radar Online productions. *   Materials stamped with control numbers related to the Radar Online production. *   Materials stamped with control numbers related to the third request (FBI-New York involvement) as a courtesy. They also correct a factual error regarding the FBI’s Florida office being part of the prosecution team.

Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The request outlines specific conditions for reviewing the evidence, primarily related to physical items seized from the Bronx warehouse and electronic media. Key points include: *   **Access to Physical Evidence:** The defense team requires access to photograph and inspect bulky, electronic, and fragile items at the Bronx warehouse, necessitating a lawyer, investigator, and paralegal presence. *   **Electronic Media Review:** The government will provide the necessary equipment to play recordings, but the defense needs to inspect the outside of the recordings. Segregation of recordings based on "witness statements" is requested. *   **Space Requirements:** The defense needs a suitable space (potentially the largest proffer room or a locked courtroom) to accommodate the team and evidence. *   **Confidentiality:**  Strict protocols are in place for handling highly confidential materials, including the 2,100 images and 7 hard-copy materials. The FBI will provide a single laptop for reviewing the electronic images. *   **Timeline:** The FBI proposes arranging for the client to be produced to 500 Pearl Street during the week of April 12th and April 19th, followed by daily reviews. *   **Ongoing Communication:** Frequent communication is essential to address any issues or disagreements, and the FBI will provide updates on the availability of equipment and the status of the evidence review. *   **Excel Spreadsheet:** The FBI provides an index of physical evidence in its custody, alongside a discovery cover letter, and requests information regarding the number of people who will be present for the physical evidence review.

The Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is producing an additional photograph as part of the discovery process in the case of *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The photograph and a cover letter are attached and will be included on a drive for the defendant’s use at the Miami-Dade College (MDC).

An email chain discusses the production of discovery materials in the case of *US v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)*. A supplemental discovery production and a cover letter were sent to counsel via FedEx from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. The materials were intended for the client, and a replacement drive containing the production was sent to the MDC.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent supplemental discovery production and a cover letter regarding the case *US v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (MN)* to Christian Everdell. The production was to be loaded onto a FedEx-sent replacement drive provided to the recipient.

The emails primarily relate to the production of electronic discovery materials to the US Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York (USANYS). **Key Points & Actions:** *   **Initial Production:** A contractor (USANYS) sent a CD containing discovery materials to the MDC (presumably the recipient's legal team). Draft cover letters and attached files (DOCX documents) were included. *   **Metadata Issues:** The USANYS team identifies significant issues with the metadata associated with many of the recovered electronic files, including missing dates, incorrect file creation/modification dates, and a lack of CART numbers. *   **Requests for Clarification & Production:** Laura Menninger requests a detailed metadata overlay for files with altered dates, asks for a list of carved/deleted files, and requests CART numbers for specific photographs. *   **Addressing the Drive Issue:** There is discussion about sending a hard drive containing the discovery to the recipient, contingent on the recipient's ability to access it. *   **Missing Attachments:** A large number of emails lack attachments, requiring the USANYS to seek these out. *   **Ongoing Investigation:** The USANYS team is investigating the Bates gap (missing files) and working with a vendor to determine the best way to convey the metadata information. *   **Confirmation of Non-Recovery:** The USANYS confirms that certain attachments were not recovered from searched devices. *   **Multiple Requests for Additional Information:** The assistant US attorney repeatedly requests more information about the discovery materials and the metadata associated with them. **Essentially, the document outlines a challenging discovery process complicated by metadata discrepancies and the need for clarification on missing files and production methods.**

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP sent an email to Judge Nathan on May 28, 2021, regarding a reply memorandum submitted by Ghislaine Maxwell in support of her supplemental pretrial motions related to the S2 Superseding Indictment in the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). The email included a cover letter and the reply memorandum, which were filed under seal. A confidentiality notice was also included within the email.

*   The trial is scheduled for November in New York. *   They are requesting FedEx records from 2008, initially obtained through a subpoena. *   A cover letter and certification from FedEx in 2008 were attached to provide relevant documentation. *   The team is seeking confirmation of someone who can sign an affidavit or provide testimony at trial. *   Communication involves multiple individuals, including paralegals and an assistant US attorney, with follow-up requests for contact information.

A contractor ([REDACTED]) is assisting the US Attorney's Office (USANYS) with a project concerning documents related to the “GM FedEx Project.” The contractor is reviewing FedEx documents, confirming they were not produced in discovery.  They have drafted a cover letter for the FedEx documents, suggesting it be stamped with specific protective order language. Additional materials are located in a shared folder and the contractor is seeking guidance on whether to stamp them as well, or solely focus on the FedEx materials. Scheduling discussions regarding a call to coordinate work are also occurring between the parties.

Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York regarding potential records for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. *   The primary goal was to identify a records custodian who could testify at trial, potentially including a witness who could appear in person. *   A subpoena was issued to FedEx in February 2008 related to the case. *   Documents, including a FedEx cover letter and certification from 2008, were provided as potential evidence. *   Tracy Ferrara of FedEx was identified as the point of contact for the subpoena. *   A request was made for an affidavit or a witness to testify, specifically referencing Jeffrey Epstein. *   The trial was scheduled to begin in New York in November 2021.

The production “Nineteenth” is ready for review, with the exception of FBI Recovered Metadata. The production, index, and cover letter are saved on a shared drive. The standard protective order stamp (“SUBJECT TO PROTECTIVE ORDER PARAGRAPHS 7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17”) is proposed for stamping the materials. A 500GB drive is requested for the FBI Recovered Metadata.  The team is coordinating with defense counsel regarding the stamping of JPMC returns and the use of a protective order stamp.

The document details the preparation of a production related to the “Nineteenth Production,” likely a legal case involving Jeffrey Epstein. Key actions include: *   Requests for modifications to an index and cover letter, specifically regarding the categorization of “FBI Recovered Metadata” (splitting it into two subfolders). *   Addition of specific language to the cover letter explaining the HTML files and file structure associated with the recovered data. *   Confirmation that the entire production is stamped and ready for review, excluding the FBI Recovered Metadata (which requires a 500GB drive). *   Discussion regarding the stamping of JP Morgan Chase returns, with a preference for using the existing protective order stamp. *   Coordination on the protective order designation to be used on all materials.

A draft cover letter (version 1.5) was sent between individuals associated with the United States Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York, on October 6, 2021. The sender requested edits to the cover letter, highlighting areas of uncertainty. The email chain involved a discussion regarding EFTA00015128.

An email was sent on October 7, 2021, regarding a draft cover letter (“3500 Cover Letter”) attached for review. The sender, an Assistant United States Attorney, questioned the phrasing of a specific clause and suggested including it in a footnote on the witness log document instead, proposing the paralegals handle this addition.

A draft cover letter for an Assistant United States Attorney position at the United States Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York (EFTA00018854) was sent by [REDACTED] on October 7, 2021. The cover letter, version 1.5, is attached.

A cover letter, titled "2021.10.11 Maxwell Cover Letter v3.docx," was sent from an unknown sender to an unknown recipient on October 10, 2021. The cover letter is attached to the email and labeled EFTA00025277.

On October 11, 2021, an Assistant United States Attorney requested specific documents be included on drives for upcoming production related to a case. The requested items were: a witness list, a cover letter, 3500 Indices, 3500 productions, GX index, GX exhibits (redacted nudity), and prior GM productions provided to defense counsel (10/4, 10/7, and the anticipated production for the following day).

A draft cover letter regarding spreadsheets production was sent by an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York on October 13, 2021. The letter is attached as a .docx file and requests suggestions for including qualifying language such as “as a courtesy.”

On October 19, 2021, a USANYS attorney sent revised Military Intelligence Letters (MILs) and related documents to a team, including [REDACTED], [REDACTED], and [REDACTED]. The documents included a redline, a draft cover letter, and a draft index letter with victim information. The MILs were the result of a significant undertaking involving witness preparation, redactions (13 identified), and ongoing issues. The attorney expressed gratitude for the team's work and anticipation for the filing.

A cover letter, dated October 25, 2021, from an Assistant United States Attorney at the United States Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York, was sent to an individual identified as "cz" (USANYS). The cover letter is attached as a .docx file titled “2021.10.25_Maxwell_Cover_Letter_v 1.docx”.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is sending additional discovery production to counsel regarding the case *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The production will be delivered via USAfx, and options for delivery are available: a CD sent to the MDC or a drive provided by the recipient.

A production related to the case *US v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN)* was shared with recipients via USAfx. The production, along with cover letters, was prepared for delivery to the MDC. Options for delivery included a CD or a drive provided by the recipient. Confirmation of the cover letters was requested.

This email discusses the production of discovery materials related to the case *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). The Assistant United States Attorney is sending an additional discovery production to Mark S. Cohen, Bobbi Sternheim, Laura Menninger, and Jeff Pagliuca via USAfx. The production will be sent to the MDC for Ms. Maxwell. Options for delivery include a CD or a provided drive, with the possibility of returning a drive to load the production. The email includes contact information for the United States Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York.

This document is a communication from the United States Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York, regarding the case *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (MN)). It includes attachments such as a cover letter, an index, various defense documents (including exhibits for a hearing scheduled for November 9, 2021), and witness material.

This document is a cover letter from the U.S. Government to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the protection of witness identities in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial (20 Cr. 330). The Government proposes specific procedures including: using witness nomenclature, a voir dire method involving a sealed list, a proposed jury instruction referencing first names or pseudonyms, and offering exhibits under seal or with redactions. The Government requests the Court accept its proposed redactions to protect victim identities and minimize potential public exposure. The defense agrees to the Government’s proposed nomenclature and procedures, but offers an alternative limiting instruction for the jury.

The following email exchange discusses the distribution of “spreadsheets” originating from Denver exports, lacking thumbnails. Key requests include: *   Updating a letter with revised Bates numbers (SDNY\_GM\_02765031-2765061). *   Removing the word “discovery” from a PDF title. *   Sharing the production via USAfx with the defense team. *   Adding Bates numbers to a cover letter. *   Sending the spreadsheets to the defense team tonight. The emails involve multiple individuals and organizations, including USANYS, NYPD, and FBI.

*   The core topic of the exchange was the preparation and distribution of “spreadsheets” originating from Denver exports, specifically regarding materials that lacked thumbnails. *   Requests were made to update cover letters, including modifying Bates ranges and removing the word "discovery" from a PDF title. *   A production of documents was prepared and shared via a shared DOJ cloud storage location. *   The sender offered to convert the materials to PDF and send them to MDC (likely a client) for review. *   The sender provided a link to the shared production files. *   There were requests for immediate delivery of the materials.

On November 16, 2021, the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York sent additional discovery materials related to *U.S. v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (MN)) to Christian Everdell, Laura Menninger, Jeff Pagliuca, and the USANYS contractor. The materials included cover letters, indices for testifying and non-testifying witness material, and exhibit indices. The production will be delivered via USAfx, and one hard drive provided by the recipient will be sent to the MDC for Ms. Maxwell.

An email chain discusses revised Medical Issue Letters (MILs) and letters related to the Maxwell case. One party ([REDACTED]) received a draft cover letter, index letter with victim information, and a redline from an Assistant United States Attorney (USANYS) of the Southern District of New York. The USANYS requests revisions to the letters, specifically suggesting language regarding Judge Nathan’s comments on Epstein and a justification for why a claim of Maxwell abuse will cause prejudicial publicity.

An email chain discusses Ms. Maxwell’s 13 motions in limine filed in the U.S. v. Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330). Nicole Simmons attached the motions and supporting cover letters from the Wisa.doj.gov cloud share drive, responding to a request for access and distribution from Nathan NYSD Chambers and Jeff Pagliuca.

On November 24, 2021, a paralegal specialist from the U.S. Attorney’s Office I SDNY requested a time-sensitive review of pending productions, specifically the TW 3500 and Rule 16 productions, along with associated cover letters. The productions were located at Wsa.doj.gov\cloud \ NYS \StAndrews\ Shared \USvEpstein-2018R01618 !Trial and included an Excel version of the indices. A password was attached to expedite the review process. The specialist needed the materials reviewed and ready for loading by 3:20 PM due to a FedEx pickup at 4:00 PM. EFTA00016482 was referenced.

The Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is sending additional discovery materials related to the case *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell* to the opposing counsel. These materials include witness statements (testifying and non-testifying), indexed documents, and cover letters. The production will be delivered via USAfx, and the attorney offers options for delivery: a CD to the MDC or a drive provided by the opposing counsel.

An email chain discusses the addition of scanned documents (a black address book and yellow legal pad notes) to pending production. The documents are marked confidential and should be indexed as specified. An updated cover letter is requested and attached. The email originates from the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force, referencing case files SDNY_GM_02753612.

Multiple individuals were coordinating the distribution of scanned documents, including a black address book and yellow legal pad notes, related to a case (referenced as SDNY_GM_02753612). Cover letters and updated descriptions were being prepared and shared via email and a CD. The documents were designated as confidential and to be sent out that evening. The materials were associated with the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force.

A cover letter, attached as a .docx file, was sent from an unknown sender to the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York regarding case file EFTA00018371. The cover letter includes a RTC and Verdict sheet.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] regarding case 3500, the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The email details the attachment of defense-related documents, including cover letters, indices, witness material, and Microsoft Word documents. These materials were uploaded to USAfx and are prepared for distribution to the defense team. The sender intends to load a drive for Maxwell and ship it via FedEx.

The United States Attorney’s Office, Southern District of New York, is sending supplemental testifying and non-testifying witness material related to the case *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (MN)) to Christian Everdell, Bobbi C Sternheim, Laura Menninger, and Jeff Pagliuca. The material, including a cover letter and indices, is being sent via USAfx and will be loaded onto a hard drive for delivery to the MDC for Ghislaine Maxwell.

Multiple individuals (identified only as “[REDACTED]”) were involved in adding the returns to various folders, including a Rule 16 production and a trial subpoena returns folder within a shared cloud storage location (W.Usa.doj.gov\ cloud\ NYS\ StAndrews SharecAUSvEpstein-2018R0161MITriaNTrial Subpoena Returns\Amazon \ 2021.11.10). An email chain discusses an Amazon return related to a legal case (USvEpstein-2018R01618). A contractor, [REDACTED], is tasked with reviewing a discovery cover letter and adding the Amazon return to production files, specifically the Rule 16 production and a folder for Amazon subpoena returns. The contractor is coordinating with an Assistant United States Attorney regarding the handling of the returns and their placement within the trial’s discovery process.

The Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is sending additional discovery materials to the defense in the case of *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell*. These materials include cover letters, witness material (testifying and non-testifying), exhibits, and indices. The production will be delivered via USAfx, including hard drives containing previously produced materials from November 9th, re-stamped Mulligan materials, and materials produced to Dr. Rocchio.

The United States Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York is sending additional discovery materials related to the case *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (MN)) to counsel. This includes a cover letter, a hard drive containing documents, and supplemental productions of testifying and non-testifying witness material and exhibits. The materials will also be available via USAfx. The sender requests confirmation regarding pickup of the hard drive or FedEx delivery options.

A contractor is preparing a discovery production for the US v. Maxwell case. This includes a Rule 16 production excluding SDNY_GM_02774100-SDNY_GM_02774104, as well as witness and exhibit materials. The materials are being sent via FedEx to both Colorado and the MDC, with tracking numbers provided.  A cover letter is attached for the hard drive containing the materials. The contractor is coordinating with USANYS counsel to determine delivery method (pickup or FedEx) and recipient locations (CO, MDC, or Ms. Maxwell at the MDC).

A communication regarding the discovery production in the case of *US v. Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). A corrected cover letter was sent to Laura Mennin, detailing a correction of an SDNY file number error (changing SDNY_GM_02774195 to SDNY_GM_02774105). Hard drives containing discovery materials were shipped to Mennin’s office in Colorado and to Maxwell’s client at the MDC via FedEx. Some Bates numbers (2774105-2774194) were missing from the production and were requested for clarification. An additional discovery production including witness material and exhibits was also being prepared for shipment via hard drive and USAfx.

The Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is submitting redacted versions of three documents to the court: a briefing on birth certificates, a remaining briefing on GX-52, and the Government’s motion to quash. The U.S. Attorney proposes a filing process involving a cover letter, redacted document submissions, and responses from the defense. The defense is not proposing any redactions to the submitted documents.

The Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is proposing redactions to Exhibit 2 of Laura Menninger's response to a court order regarding the Dietz/Loftus case. The proposed redactions are attached as “Ex._1_[proposed_redactions].pdf” and will be sent to the Court for docketing once approved.

A legal production, including Rule 16 and 3500 productions, related to the U.S. v. Maxwell case, was prepared and sent to defense counsel via FedEx drive. The drive and password were provided with tracking numbers. The production was uploaded to USAfx. A time-sensitive review of the 3500 index was requested, and the materials were located on Msa.doj.gov\cloud NYS. Cover letters and Excel indices were attached for review and potential changes.

A paralegal specialist at the U.S. Attorney’s Office I SDNY is requesting a time-sensitive review and approval of three productions related to a case (U.S. v Maxwell) to ensure they are ready for distribution via FedEx by 4:00 PM today. The productions are the 1W 3500, NTW 3500, and a 32nd production. Supporting documents, including cover letters and Excel indices, are attached.

The Southern District of New York’s Assistant United States Attorney sent replacement discovery materials related to the US v. Maxwell case (20 CR. 330 (MN)). These materials included documents with corrected Bates numbers, a cover letter, and a disc containing the revised documents for the MDC. The original documents had been incorrectly labeled with Bates numbers.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP submitted documents to Judge Nathan regarding Ghislaine Maxwell’s bail motion in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330 (MN)). The submissions included a cover letter, an unredacted renewed bail motion, and unredacted exhibits A-E. These documents were sent under seal due to the volume of materials.

A communication was sent via FedEx containing a small corrected production of discovery to Maxwell. The communication was from the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, along with associated cover letters and PDFs related to the “Maxwell discovery” production.

Seven items, including one Excel file and six PDFs, need to be reproduced due to incorrect Bates numbers. These items originated from the 7th and 8th productions related to a case involving Maxwell and the MDC. A cover letter detailing the reproduced items and their updated Bates ranges was drafted. A CD containing the reproduced items was to be sent to the MDC that afternoon.

Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP submitted documents to Judge Nathan in the case of *U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell* (20 Cr. 330 (MN)) under seal. The documents included a cover letter, an unredacted reply memorandum, a redacted reply memorandum, and accompanying exhibits A and B. The submission was in response to a renewed bail motion.
